Truly amazing adrenaline fun game. 
This autobattler stands out with mature, high-quality graphics‚Äîno childish animations or goofy monsters here. It blends elements of deck-building, war strategy, autobattling, and light economy management into a unique experience.
The best part? There‚Äôs minimal RNG. When I lose, I can review the replay, replay the turn, and clearly see what I did wrong. I never feel like defeat comes down to luck. If I lose, it‚Äôs because the other player was stronger or because I made a mistake‚Äîor a series of mistakes‚Äîthat led to my downfall.

I played a similar game called Minion Masters (more TCG) for years, even though I never really enjoyed the graphics‚Äîthe colors felt too bright and the UI too childish for my taste. What kept me hooked was the core concept of deck-building combined with autobattler.
Mechabellum takes that foundation and adds a fascinating twist: turns and an economy system that force you to make strategic choices between units and tactics. 

You can win a game even if you lost 3 rounds in a row. There are some snowball tactics, but if you know how to deal with them, there is always the hope of a glorious come back. 

It‚Äôs an excellent game, and I truly hope the developers find a sustainable way to monetize it in the long run. ¬£12 is a complete bargain for what you get, even if you play only vs AI or the one turn puzzle games. 

Unlike other titles that overwhelm you with hundreds of units, Mechabellum focuses on a smaller roster. The design encourages you to upgrade and adapt units to fulfill different roles, which makes matches less predictable and pushes you to adjust your strategies dynamically. 

PROS: 
-	Graphics and sound design.
-	War strategy with cold calculations between turns and adrenaline rushes viewing the results of your choices in a beautiful and desructive battle.
-	Developers constantly working on the game, adding units, balancing the game and expanding the ways to play.
-	Great Youtubers to learn startegies and enjoy watching them like RoosterPB, Oddz, Stoney, Yuban‚Ä¶
-	There is a solo game mode to learn how to play before playing online and puzzles to solve.
-	As far as it gets from a pay to win game.
CONS:
-	Not a game to play after a stressful day at work or before going to bed.
-	It takes time to learn the basic strategies, the functions of each unit and the counters to them, but in the long run is what makes the game amazing.

This game is supposed to be a strategy auto-battler, yet the thing that has the greatest impact in the game is RNG. In literally every part of the game too.

It starts with the character and your starting units packs, both of which you pick at the start of the match. Both are picked blindly, i.e. what your opponent has is pretty much random, and have very one sided match ups. Then there's the initial positioning of your units, which is also blind, i.e. what positioning you're up against is basically random too. From there the game usually just snowballs. The only thing that can then save your opponent or yourself, is usually getting the right Unit drops or Spells to salvage the situation. Both of those are up to your choice, but are picked out of a, surprise, randomised subset of what's available in the game overall. Didn't roll the right options to choose from with respect to the current game state? Guess that's a loss then!

So, aside from learning some basic things, like not putting your vulnerable DPS units in front of your cannon fodder and what unit counters what other unit, there isn't much you can do that actually seems to matter. Because of this wins usually feel like you [i]didn't[/i] do anything and losses feel like you [i]couldn't[/i] do anything.

They had a good "fancy chess" game, but it is quickly spiraling into a convoluted mess that requires the use of units that are no fun to play that counter literally every strategy simply by stealing all their opponents units. And the way the math works out, you "can't" steal your unit back.  

This game seems to be suffering from "exponential power"; I started at the end of season 1, and i think its on season 5 now (id look, but i just uninstalled). As they add units, the new units are "over-tuned" to get players to use them (i don't like it, but it's a necessary evil) and the devs are pretty good about balancing after a couple weeks. Even with the unneeded class of "titan" units (tier 5), there are tier 4 (giant) units that can be used to counter them.  But this is kind of where the issue starts to show its teeth. Instead of being a "chess like" or "rock-paper-scissors" style game, the added units make it a "rock-paper-scissors-dynamite" game, but dynamite is OP for winning 2* battles, so they make it "rock-paper-scissors-dynamite-water", but water also defeats paper, so now they tune "paper" to "laminated paper" but now scissors struggles to win against paper, so they add a new unit called paper weight, but then it has its problems and throws the balance out even further, and so on. 

But the main reason I uninstalled was the over tuning of a previously unused unit: the hacker. It used to be an unused unit because it would take forever to "hack" a unit, and it had fairly limited range and very little HP, and was generally countered "naturally" while countering other units. At some point around season 3? (i remember reading the patch notes, but dk when) they started trying to make it a relevant unit. in doing so, they made it one of the single most powerful units in the game. Its whole thing is that it can "hack" a unit and make it permanently* switch sides(unless it is hacked back) and for a few credits more, it will not only hack, but instantly heal that unit back to full health. Either one of those is kind of OP, but add the affect of causing all your units (that are close enough to fire on the hacked unit) to break contact with w/e they are currently shooting, to stop, turn, and then start shooting at the hacked unit.  And with the tuning of the "hacker" they made it so a Level 3 hacker can hack t5 units in about 4 seconds, t4 in about 1.5, t3 in less than 1.   The ONLY* way to counter this is to also add your own hackers, however, there are certain starting cards (each side gets different ones) and round cards (each side gets the same) that can cause one side to have an un-countereable advantage, and this isn't a "if the stars align" scenario, this is a "1 in 5 matches" scenario, if not more.  Air units were a potential counter, however, there are so many units that counter air,  that they might as well not be considered be a counter.  And the way the math works out, if they hack your unit, you "can't" hack it back because it will turn and obliterate your hacker before it can be hacked back. And setting up your hacker to recapture your own units requires you to spend a whole turn focused on that, which sets off an unstoppable chain-reaction spiral.

In summary, I liked the game, and liked the way that it was headed. However, one side being able to deploy an over tuned unit significantly earlier than the other side, and that unit keeps getting buffed, or supporting units that make it literally un-counterable made this game not fun.  IDC about the Titan unit that can be dropped on round 2 that can stand in the back and kill both chaff/swarm units and heavy units, anywhere on the map, without moving.  But having a unit that can capture/convert equal tier or higher units to full heath in less 2 seconds completely breaks the game because unless you are prepared for that strategy ahead of time, there is no way to counter it. (and by preparing for that one strategy, it leaves you wide open to several other strategies.

I played Mechabellum pretty regularly until the second patch for the building update came out and have put it down for now due to frustrating design decisions. I'm sure if people could comment many of them would say "get good" but realistically the game is just less fun since I don't mind losing as long as things feel fair and like I was outplayed. So why a negative review after nearly 90 hours? The game is fairly priced, the anti-cheat works great, and the gameplay has a lot to offer. It just isn't fun any more.

As I noted above the buildings update was a big problem and the number of players has been steadily dropping since. The devs will say this is because they stopped doing marketing or whatever but in the long run it doesn't really matter why it is happening but it is happening and I'm one of those people. Buildings added more annoyances to the game. Why do my air units which are unaffected by walls and turrets even target them to begin with? Air units are already in a pretty weak spot based on top performing players yet they have more silly actions like this. Units also attack walls even while getting hammered on by other units. The logic doesn't really make sense and this is the problem with buildings in general. They add more annoyances and nuances. The game is already quite difficult to learn and many mechanics are hidden or not properly explained and buildings add even more of that. It's not fun to watch your units attack a wall or tiny turret when there is an enemy destroying them because that's just how the game logic works.

In addition to the frustration added by buildings unit drops (this is where between certain rounds you get to choose from a selection of units to receive) were recently modified. I started playing after those and spells were introduced (more on them later) so I didn't hate them even though I thought they were kind of lame but when the best decision even after tweaking them is to pick the most expensive unit (which the UI doesn't note when picking a unit drop) and sell it that makes you think there might be a bigger problem with how that is designed yet it is still in the game.

Then you have castable spells as they are called in the game. The majority of these aren't a big deal or that game breaking yet a few late game ones (specifically the nuke and storm cloud) can be devastating and remove choices as you essentially have to pick them or spend a ton of resources on countering them since they do so much damage in such a wide area. Sure you can counter this by spreading out your board more but it makes the later rounds feel so swingy and contributes very little. It's like the desire is to just see a big explosion of units rather than balance because it looks cool while harming the strategic layer of the game.

Recently more titan units (really big and expensive but potentially game changing units) were added to 1V1. I don't like titan units. I think they're kind of cheesy and lame gut punch attempts that detract from the game especially in a 1V1 scenario. It was recently announced that they're going to add a titan unit which is centered around fire, essentially either an AoE on the ground that does damage over time, or straight damage over time. This is dismaying to hear because dealing with fire is already quite annoying and not very fun. Only one unit can counter fire that is on the ground and adding a titan that specializes in creating fire instead of dealing with it in other ways makes me really wonder what is going on design wise. The devs said they were going to stop adding units for a while to focus on QoL but immediately after they say a new titan is coming.

QoL issues also abound and while the devs have been improving this lately it's still a problem. You can't automatically mute all the chats every time you start the game and have to mute some every time. Why? You have to reset the camera to your preferred position every game. You have to select which queue you want to play (ranked versus unranked) every time. Having to click "speed up" every round instead of toggling it is especially annoying and has been a problem for a long time. The list of these issues goes on and on and is especially present in game where information is simply lacking around exactly what units do, what type of weapon they fire, how much they cost during drops, what techs you have on them before you buy them, etc. Thankfully some of these issues were fixed thanks to the undo button that was recently implemented but is it really a positive when the best course of action is to do something, see information, then undo it? I don't think so. Performance has also been pretty bad recently even on higher end machines in the later rounds because so much is happening on screen.

Overall the game feels like it isn't in a great place right now. Buildings didn't create the problem but they were the straw that broke the camel's back for many players as it introduced one more annoyance and frustration to the game and while the devs did introduce some changes buildings still exist and didn't fix the underlying problem they were meant to.

Right now I can't recommend Mechabellum. Maybe in the future it will be in a better place but I'm done for now.

In the late game, the introduction of Nukes and Storms creates a massive disparity in army sizes, often determining the winner based on who executes their spells better. While these spells have the potential for dramatic moments, their impact can feel rushed in a game that already has a slow pace. This mechanic disrupts the pacing and feels like a way to force an end to the match, preventing longer games.

Additionally, the game speed is quite slow, and there is no option to auto-speed up matches. This can lead to fights lasting up to 30 minutes unless one player snowballs and dominates the opponent, making each match a significant time commitment.

Lastly, there is no true 2vs2 mode; instead, it‚Äôs essentially two 1vs1 matches happening simultaneously. The winning sides then meet in the middle to battle with their remaining units. TLDR: They reinvented "chess" and made "fancy chess". But then they added a nerfed game breaking unit that converts units almost instantly,  and keep buffing it.  They also seem to be trying to turn a 20-30minute match into an hour long match by adding more and more tiers of units. They had a good "fancy chess" game, but it is quickly spiraling into a convoluted mess that requires the use of units that are no fun to play that counter literally every strategy simply by stealing all their opponents units. And the way the math works out, you "can't" steal your unit back.  

This game seems to be suffering from "exponential power"; I started at the end of season 1, and i think its on season 5 now (id look, but i just uninstalled). As they add units, the new units are "over-tuned" to get players to use them (i don't like it, but it's a necessary evil) and the devs are pretty good about balancing after a couple weeks. Even with the unneeded class of "titan" units (tier 5), there are tier 4 (giant) units that can be used to counter them.  But this is kind of where the issue starts to show its teeth. Instead of being a "chess like" or "rock-paper-scissors" style game, the added units make it a "rock-paper-scissors-dynamite" game, but dynamite is OP for winning 2* battles, so they make it "rock-paper-scissors-dynamite-water", but water also defeats paper, so now they tune "paper" to "laminated paper" but now scissors struggles to win against paper, so they add a new unit called paper weight, but then it has its problems and throws the balance out even further, and so on. 

But the main reason I uninstalled was the over tuning of a previously unused unit: the hacker. It used to be an unused unit because it would take forever to "hack" a unit, and it had fairly limited range and very little HP, and was generally countered "naturally" while countering other units. At some point around season 3? (i remember reading the patch notes, but dk when) they started trying to make it a relevant unit. in doing so, they made it one of the single most powerful units in the game. Its whole thing is that it can "hack" a unit and make it permanently* switch sides(unless it is hacked back) and for a few credits more, it will not only hack, but instantly heal that unit back to full health. Either one of those is kind of OP, but add the affect of causing all your units (that are close enough to fire on the hacked unit) to break contact with w/e they are currently shooting, to stop, turn, and then start shooting at the hacked unit.  And with the tuning of the "hacker" they made it so a Level 3 hacker can hack t5 units in about 4 seconds, t4 in about 1.5, t3 in less than 1.   The ONLY* way to counter this is to also add your own hackers, however, there are certain starting cards (each side gets different ones) and round cards (each side gets the same) that can cause one side to have an un-countereable advantage, and this isn't a "if the stars align" scenario, this is a "1 in 5 matches" scenario, if not more.  Air units were a potential counter, however, there are so many units that counter air,  that they might as well not be considered be a counter.  And the way the math works out, if they hack your unit, you "can't" hack it back because it will turn and obliterate your hacker before it can be hacked back. And setting up your hacker to recapture your own units requires you to spend a whole turn focused on that, which sets off an unstoppable chain-reaction spiral.

In summary, I liked the game, and liked the way that it was headed. However, one side being able to deploy an over tuned unit significantly earlier than the other side, and that unit keeps getting buffed, or supporting units that make it literally un-counterable made this game not fun.  IDC about the Titan unit that can be dropped on round 2 that can stand in the back and kill both chaff/swarm units and heavy units, anywhere on the map, without moving.  But having a unit that can capture/convert equal tier or higher units to full heath in less 2 seconds completely breaks the game because unless you are prepared for that strategy ahead of time, there is no way to counter it. (and by preparing for that one strategy, it leaves you wide open to several other strategies.
